reasoning:
Both Grand Tree and Mesagoza are Stadium cards in the Pokémon TCG that provide deck-searching effects for Evolution Pokémon. Grand Tree allows you to search your deck for an Evolution Pokémon once per turn, while Mesagoza lets you look at the top 7 cards and put up to 2 Stage 1 or Stage 2 Pokémon into your hand. They serve highly similar functions as deck consistency tools for evolution-based strategies like Charizard Pidgeot, which relies heavily on setting up evolved Pokémon. Both are searchable via the same methods (Stadium search cards) and occupy the same Stadium slot.

However, they're not perfect substitutes: Mesagoza is generally more powerful as it can grab 2 Pokémon at once and digs deeper (7 cards), while Grand Tree is more flexible (works on any Evolution including Stage 1s used as basics in some formats) but only gets 1 card per turn. Mesagoza is typically the stronger choice in most evolution decks, but Grand Tree offers repeated value. The score reflects strong functional similarity with meaningful but not fundamental differences in execution.
